dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WADE WHITEHOUSE, driving, sits beside JILL, his daughter, ten years-old, wearing a black-and-yellow tiger plastic m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry for the screw-up. But I  couldn't help it it's too late to go  trick-or-treating now. I couldn't  help it I had to stop at Penny's for  the costume. And you were hungry,  remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's fault is it then if it's not  yours? You're the one in charge,  Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes cigarette  from pack) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. Those kids are still trick-or- treating. They're still out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade watches boys in the headlights, lights cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are the Hoyts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care. They're out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you see... look out there.  Nobody's got their porch lights on  anymore. It's too late. Those Hoyt  kids are just out to get in trouble.  See, they put shaving cream all over  that mailbox there. They chopped  down Herb Crane's new bushes. Little  bastards. Jesus H. Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade grimaces, holds his jaw. The Fairlane swerves around broken pumpkins under a caution light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do they do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Break stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess they're stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you do that when you were a kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yeah. Sort of. Nothing really  mean. Me and my pals, me and my  brothers. It was kind of funny then.  Stealing pumpkins, soaping windows.  Stuff like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To us it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's not funny now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not funny now. I'm a cop and I  gotta listen to all the complaints  people make. I'm not a kid anymore.  You change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you did lots of bad things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just think you used to be bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I didn't used to be bad. No sir.  Where do you get this stuff? From  your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. She doesn't talk about you  anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade looks at her, wanting to lift her mask, see her face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fairlane approaches Town Hall, a square two-story bui on the north side of the Common. Exhaust billows from idl cars as parents and children come and go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clowns, tramps, angels and vampires fill the brightly lit room. Parents watch from the walls as GORDON LARIVIERE, a beefy fiftiesh man with a silver flat-top, announces the  costume contest. Wade nods to various townspeople.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're looking for the funniest  costume! And the scariest! And the  most imaginative! And the best costume  of all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nudges Jill) Got here just in time. Go ahead.  Jump in line. Maybe you'll win a  prize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill steps forward, retreats. Wade looks at her flaxen ha her blue sneakers protruding from her pathetic costume. H heart aches he loves her so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, Jill. Some of those kids you  still know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Why not? You know these kids  from when you went to school here.  It hasn't been that long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice breaking) I want to go home. (Wade kneels down) I don't like it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, come on, will you? Don't  mess this up anymore than it's already  been messed up. Join the other kids.  Do that and before you know it you'll  be as happy as a goddamned clam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade inches her toward the circle of children. Gordon spo them:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade! And who's that tiger? Is that  Jill? Come and join us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill in the spotlight, joins the costumed children. A for classmate calls her name. Wade, relieved, watches, then s outside for a smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade steps outside, lights a cigarette. JACK HEWITT, 23,  clean-cut, handsome, cocky, stands with CHICK WARD and FR LACOY, local boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you boys up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same old shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see the damage these little sons- of bitches been raising tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack) You're going to have to move your  pickup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offers whiskey pint) Take a bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mind if I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LaRiviere's having a hell of a time  in there. Master of fucking  ceremonies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's that gun you were bragging  on today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stops over to his double-parked burgandy pickup, rem a Browning BAR .30/06 with a scope, hands it to Wade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No brag. Just fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (admires gun) Got you for -- 450, 500 bucks? (passes it to Frankie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Wade) See you got Jill tonight. How'd you  manage that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns) Don't forget to move your truck. (walks inside)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On stage, LaRiviere arranges the contest winners. A fairy godmother with a wand beams while, nearby, a hobo writhes his mother's grip -- a hard loser. Wade looks for Jill, first among the winners, then among losers; she's nowhere to be found. He heads toward a hall leading to the restrooms. Jill stands alone in the corner next to the pay phone, ti forlorn. Wade realizes at once he was wrong to leave her  before she had found a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some party, huh? Sorry I lost sight  of you. I had to step outside for a  smoke. You find anybody you know  here? There must be some kids you  used to know from school. You want  to go tomorrow? See your old teachers?  Be more fun than hanging out with me  all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lifts mask atop head) No I didn't see anybody I know. No I  don't want to go to school here  tomorrow. I want to go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are home. There are lots of kids  you still know here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be here. Don't worry,  I love you, Daddy, I do. But I want  to go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) Jesus. Listen, Jill, tell you what.  Tomorrow morning, you still want to  go home, I'll drive you down. I'll  get off work or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) I called Mommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You called Mommy? Just now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... because I want to go home. She  said she'd come and get me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come and get you! Shit! It's a damn  half hour drive each way. Why didn't  you talk to me about it first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, I knew you'd be mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah, right, I'm mad. What'd  you tell her, for Christ sake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told her I wanted to come home.  Daddy, don't be mad at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I am. I planned this,  I planned all this, you know. I mean,  it's sort of pathetic, but I planned  it. You shouldn't have called your  mother. (takes her arm) C'mon, we're gonna call her before  she leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade leads her to a frosted-glass door reading "POLICE",  enters. Inside, he flips on flourescent light, dials the  desk phone. More utility room than office. He waits. There's no answer. Jill looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's gone already! (hangs up) Gone already! Couldn't wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all you got to say? "Yes".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She won't be here for a half hour.  Think you can stand it that long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you expect to wait for her?  Obviously downstairs with the other  kids isn't good enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill sits in a chair facing the dark window pane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit right there by yourself if you  want. Wait for her by yourself. That's  fine with me. Just dandy. I'm going  downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine with me too. When Mommy  comes, tell her I'm up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade Whitehouse stalks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade steps outside, notices Jack Hewitt and his kewpie-do girlfriend HETTIE, 20, sitting in the cab of his double-p pickup, sharing a joint, talking to LaCoy alongside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I told you to move that  truck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, Chief. We're leaving. You  wanna toke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (steps over) You gotta be more careful about that  shit. Gordon or one of those guys  sees you smoking that wacky tabacky  around me they'll expect me to bust  you. And I'll be outta a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some job. Here, have a hit. Don't be  such a hardass. I know you got  problems, but everybody's got  problems. (offers joint)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LaCoy laughs: that Jack Hewitt, some guy. Wade holds his  aching jaw. He looks at Jack's young athletic body, his p girlfriend, envies him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, c'mon, then. Get in and we'll  take a little ride, my man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade looks up to the window where Jill waits, walks aroun the front of the truck, gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's high-bodied pickup growls in low gear as it drives past Merritt's Shell station toward Saddleback Ridge. Jac lowers the radio as Wade asks him about deer season; Hett leans forward to hear the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a job first thing in the morning,  first day of season. Saturday I'll  hunt for myself. Twombley something. - Er --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evan. He's a mucky-muck union official  from Massachusetts. You're lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know about lucky. The guy's a  full-blown asshole. Pay's good,  though. $100 a day. I got to guarantee  a kill, of course. Which I can do.  There's some monster bucks hiding  out up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you get the job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon, he's always got some angle  working. He wants to keep Twombley  happy, I'm his boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade grimaces as he passes the joint back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toothache. (to Jack) You should get close to him. Make  yourself irreplaceable. Guy's loaded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you and Gordon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. The sonofabitch couldn't get  along without me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Yeah, he'd go broke tomorrow if you  quit him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car flashes past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bastard's got his high beams on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching) Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My ex-wife Lillian and her husband.  That was them in the Audi that just  passed us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audi's a good car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she up here for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, shit, she's here to get Jill. Me  and Jill had a little argument. Jack,  I got to get back, get back to town.  Move this thing, will you? See if  you can get back to the Town Hall  before they get there, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piece of fucking cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack brakes, wheels the 4x4 around, heads back to town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most parents have left or are leaving with their costumed children. Hewitt's burgundy pickup breaks alongside the A Wade swings open the passenger door, jumps to the ground:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lillian!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Jill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LILLIAN, 40, attractive in an ankle-length hooded coat.  Whatever pose Wade strikes, she strikes the opposite. Her dress and demeanor set her apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and Jill, we just had a little  spat. She felt kind of left out, I  guess, from not knowing some of the  new kids --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she now? Is she in the truck  with your friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Hettie neck inside the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She told me she wanted to wait for  you. Inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill at the window in her tiger mask. Lillian waves; Jill motions she'll be down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While you went off for a few beers  with your friends? Is that Hettie  Rodgers there, with whatzizname?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's grown up some, hasn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, lay off, will you? It  looks like you've won this fucking  round already, so lay off a little,  for Christ's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HORNER, 45, Lillian's new husband, thin with thinning hai and a Tyrolean hat, sees Jill at the entrance and heads t her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horner! Leave her be. This's got  nothing to do with you, so just act  like the chauffeur. Got it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade. Nobody wants any trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horner greets Jill, walks her to the silver Audi. Passing parents, listening, give Wade a wide berth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want her to go, Lillian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't cause a scene. No one's trying  to win any 'rounds'. Don't make it  any worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not making it any worse. You  are. Me and Jill could've worked  this thing out. It's normal, it's  even normal for me to get a little  touchy about it. Believe it or not.  How do you think this makes me look,  treating her like some tragic victim  or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horner opens the car door for Jill, shuts it. Wade shoves him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wait till we're through,  goddamnit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horner's hat falls. Lillian, icy, stares at Wade. He back off. Wade sometimes wonders: how'd Lillian Pittman of Law N.H., get so much class?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you say a word. I didn't hit  him. I'm not going to hit anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horner sits behind the wheel. Lillian silently stares Wad up and down, gets in the car beside Jill. The automatic l latch as the Audi drives away. Its taillights merge with  vanishing traffic. Wade looks down, picks up Horner's dark green Tyrolean ha examines it, as if unsure of its function. Wade walks toward Town Hall. MARGIE FOGG, exiting, greets him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New hat? (no answer) Jill's up, I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vague) For a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's she doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. She's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two want to do anything tomorrow  and need a third party, give me a  call, okay? I'm off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICK WICKHAM, 45, Marg's boss, passes by:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like hell you are. Tomorrow's first  day of deer season. I'll need you at  least in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Well, that's that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walks off) Take care, Wade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You be careful of that little bastard.  He's dying to get in your pants, you  know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Don't worry. I can protect my virtue.  I mean, c'mon, Wade, give me a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you tomorrow, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, lost in thought, continues toward Town Hall. At the door, LaRiviere, one of the last to leave, eyes him. Wade tosses Horner's hat inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch this snow. It's coming down  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade nods as he lights a cigarette. Alone, he watches the last cars pull out. He holds his jaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pre-dawn light silhouettes a dozen weather-beaten mobile  homes set off Route 29. Snow continues to fall. A sheet o white stretches down Parker mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6:40. A clock radio pierces the silence with classic rock Wade Whitehouse rolls over, runs his tongue across mossy  teeth, shuts off the music. He looks out the window, grun "Shit!" He steps over to the phone by the frayed plaid co dials. Wade's trailer is surprisingly neat, considering its owne smokes too much, drinks too much, eats take-out and rarel cleans up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Lugene? Wade. Hoya doin? (fumbles for cigarette) Look, I was wondering, with the snow  and all, if you got school today? (lights cigarette) How the hell do I know? You're the  principal. All I'm supposed to do is  direct traffic from 7:30 to 8:30. (listens) Yeah, okay, I'm sorry -- I only just  now saw it was snowing, that's all.  My whole day is fucked. I gotta plow  all day. If I don't get over to  LaRiviere's early enough, I'm stuck  with the grader. I was just hoping  you'd have called school off. (beat) You check the weather bureau? (acquiesces) Okay, I hear you. I'll be over in a  bit. (hangs up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Hewitt's 4x4 passes Wade's trailer, continues up 29. Tire chains splice the path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack behind the wheel. Beside him EVAN TWOMBLEY, 60, fles Irish, wearing brand new scarlet wool pants, jacket and c He feeds on the misfortunes of others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not enough snow, not for tracking  the bastards. No advantage there,  kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Mr. Twombley, I know  where those suckers are. Rain or  shine, snow or no snow. I know deer.  We'll kill us a buck today.  Guaranteed. Before ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guaranteed, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. Right about now the does are  holing up in the brush piles. The  bucks are right behind them and we're  right behind the bucks. (gestures to gun rack) This gun gets fired before ten  o'clock. Whether it kills a deer or  not is more less up to you. I'll put  you inside 30, 35 yards of a buck  the first four hours of the season.  That's what you're paying me for,  ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn straight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hewitt looks at Twombley's rifle: a Winchester M-94 pump- action, custom carved stock and not a scratch on it. Neve fired, at least not by Twombley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done much shooting with that rifle  yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes him) Tell you what. You get me close to a  big buck by ten, kid, there's another  hundred bucks in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might not kill it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might gut-shoot it or cripple it  for somebody else to find and tag.  Can't guarantee that won't happen,  especially with a new gun. I may  have to shoot it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take care of your end, kid, I'll  take care of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand what I'm saying? I  want a deer, a dead one, not a cripple  or whatthefuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get it. (disdain) No sweat. You'll get yourself a deer  and you'll get him dead. And you'll  have him by coffee time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you'll get your extra hundred  bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Wonderful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickup disappears behind a curve of pine and spruce t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade Whitehouse, wearing a reflective vest, waves a distr school bus into the parking lot. Noisy, jostling grade  schoolers emerge from the bus. Jill's former classmates.  Straight as a statue, Wade holds back traffic. Cars and t are backed up on the unplowed road. Horns honk and bleat; woman's voice yells, "Whitehouse, we 'ain't got all day!" Wade, daydreaming, seems oblivious to the commotion. Obli or just plum contrary. A shiny black BMW approaches, speeding, passing traffic o the shoulder. A man and a woman in a fur coat sit in fron two children in back. Whitehouse waves for it to stop. The BMW accelerates through the intersection, ignoring Wa and the traffic. It whizzes past, spinning Wade, and is  quickly up the road, spewing ice and exhaust. Wade slips one knee. Honking ensues; every car goes where it wishes. Wade, brushing off snow, follows the last bus as it pulls in. LUGENE BROOKS, 60, school principal, rushes over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay, Wade? What was wrong?  Why were you holding everyone up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see that sonofabitch in the  BMW? He could've killed somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get his number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mel Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still don't understand --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Boston. Evan Twombley's son-in- law -- he was driving. I know where  they're headed. Up the lake, Agaway.  The old man's out deer hunting with  Jack Hewitt, so they probably got  some big weekend party planned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade sets his face, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snowprints lead from Jack's pickup to where he and Twombl walk, guns pointed skyward. They enter a line of trees. Jack watches Twombley walk ahead of him, wrapped like a h infant in red bunting, crunching twigs underfoot. He look from side to side, checks his gun, returns to watching  Twombley. They're alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Safety on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twombley nods, slips, thumps to the ground. His rifle lan silently. Jack sprints over, helps him up, safety latches the  Winchester. Hands it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow close. We'll cross the next  meadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack finds a path, one eye on Twombley:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to play ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drafted by the Red Sox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You played for the Sox?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Double A. New Britain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pitcher. "Best ballplayer to come  out of New Hampshire since Carlton  Fisk."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only difference between me and  that Clemens on TV is luck, shit  luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruined my arm. Brought me along too  fast. Why'd it have to be my fucking  arm, I used to think. Then I realized  it had to be somebody's fucking arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack waits for Twombley as they enter a meadow. Jack aims his rifle at Twombley as he approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Hewitt! Slow the fuck down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack aims away, following an imaginary bird. Twombley ste alongside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Safety on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking loudly) Sun's gettin high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fingers to lips) Deers have ears too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milky sky flatters LaRiviere Co., a sprawl of well-diggin septic and snow plow equipment. Billboard declaimes:  "LARIVIERE CO. -- OUR BUSINESS IS GOING IN THE HOLE!" a m repeated on every truck and piece of equipment. Wade's gr Fairlane is parked outside the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, puffing a cigarette, passes ELAINE'S (LaRiviere  secretary) desk, her large red "No Smoking" sign, eases i an office modum chair. He unzips his jacket, slaps his ca against his thigh, spraying drops of melted snow. Gordon LaRiviere, speaking on the phone past a glass  partition, calls to Wade:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told you the snow was coming down.  Take the grader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the plow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy took it. Jack's out hunting  with Evan Twombley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His son-in-law damn near killed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hangs up) Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the school crossing. In his BMW.  Coulda hurt some kids. I'm gonna  bust his ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go playing policeman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I -- a security guard? You  hired me, you and your Selectman  friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want the extra police pay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not saying that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the grader. Go out 29 past Toby's.  Don't let Lillian get to you. She  didn't belong here. That's why she  left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I love about a small  town. You know everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade exits toward the blue grader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Twombley walk through fresh snow. The hillside's thick with pine trees. Twombley, red-faced, puffing, lean to speak to Hewitt. Jack lifts a finger to his lips:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay here, stand where I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twombley peers over a slight cliff at a lumber trail twen feet below. Jack points:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fresh tracks. (sniffs) Deer shit. Big one. Here's your buck,  Mr. Twombley. I'll circle around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You only got a little while if you  want your hundred bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack zig-zags down the incline, while Twombley, gun poise waddles along the edge. Jack stops fifty feet away, watches Twombley, a cartoon  character. A stag pokes his nose through the pines, steps into a clearing. Jack aims his rifle, looks at Twombley. Twombley turns to see the buck, loses his footing, TUMBLE down the twenty-foot cliff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An open cab grader ("Our Business Is Going In The Hole")  sits in the rutted lot outside Toby's, a beer joint with  fake wood siding and 24-hour neon sign. A four-wheel drive plow with the LaRiviere motto pulls in parks beside the blue grader. JIMMY DAME, 40, gets out,  glances at the grader as he enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy joins Wade at the bar, calls for a beer. Frankie La bullshits with two long-haired locals at a nearby table;  their conversation drifts in and out. Country music plays through a broken juke box speaker. Wade touches his tooth grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it goin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cold. How you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about that. Why's it every  year, come first snow, you get stuck  with the grader?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: School. Traffic crossing. (lights cigarette) I gotta quit these things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we doing after? Wells? (Wade nods) Don't work too fast. Business the  way it is, Gordon's probably looking  to lay me off earlier than usual  this year. He's got too much money  as it is. Why's it always the little  guy that gets kicked in the butt in  hard times?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade shrugs. LaCoy's conversation has caught his ear. He  turns to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...That was no pisser. I'll tell you  who was a pisser. Glen Whitehouse.  There was a real pisser. He was mean  normal, but when he drank it was  like he burst on fire. Canadian Club.  Always drank CC. One Christmas there's  this cord of wood out back he forgot  about and he decides to have his two  boys stack it. Except it's been out  back two months and it's snowed and  rained and froze so now the wood's  all iced in. He takes the boys. He  was drunk, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade's face as the story comes to life:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty years before. GLEN WHITEHOUSE ("POP"), 42, pushes boys, Wade (13) and Rolfe (10), toward snow-covered lumps firewood behind the barn. He's drunk. The boys carry shov and a pickaxe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move it! Daylight in the swamps!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop, the kids are waiting for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reproving) Rolfe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lesson in work and its rewards.  You'll thank me for this one day. (to house) Sally, turn off that TV!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His sons chip at the wood. Hopeless. Frozen solid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rolfe) Just do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atta-go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Pop. Let's go back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade notices his mother, SALLY, watching from the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you, a quitter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LaCoy roars with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) So what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beats me. That's all I heard. Wade  would know more about it. (calls) Wade! We were just talking about  your Old Man. "What are you, a  quitter!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade grabs his keys, walks over. Jimmy follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, LaCoy, you got nothing better  to do than sit around and tell  stories. Pity is, some college student  will come some day and believe this  shit cause you're the only one dumb  enough to talk to him. Take care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade and Jimmy head out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, shivering in the open grader, plows a narrow windin road. He lights a cigarette, exhales steamy smoke. LaCoy' laugh triggers a memory:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flashback continues: Glen Whitehouse pushes his sons  inside. Sally steps from sight. Out back, the firewood li frozen amid futile shovel marks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was some job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll work at it everyday, promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we made the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbles) You just needed a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop, swigging Canadian Club, turns:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that? (no answer) You got something to say, say it!  Say it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft) Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You no-good pup!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rolfe runs from the room screaming, "Mom!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The town's 24-hour restaurant. A bright new sign reads: " Made Cooking." Wade's grader out front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, eating lunch at the counter, talks with Nick Wickha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It don't look right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sign. It looks like it's spelled  wrong or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck. Wade Whitehouse. It's people  like you that keep this fucking town  from prospering. Whatever somebody  does to improve things around here,  you gotta find fault with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not finding fault. It's a good  idea, good for you, good for the  town. Real modern too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This town sucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, c'mon, I was only saying there's  something wrong with "Home Made  Cooking", that's all. The sign's  fine. What it says is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margie Fogg heads over, sits:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who needs it? Everybody who comes  here has been coming for years so  what they need a sign for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick goes back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about what I said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About you and Jill and needing a  third person. She went back to  Lillian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touches his arm) I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to start one of those  custody suits. I don't give a fucking  shit. You know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade's eyes well up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't mean that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I mean that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (arm around his  shoulders) No you don't. You're pissed, that's  all. You ought to cool off for a few  days then have a long talk with  Lillian. You know? Work it out with  her, tell her how you feel. Lillian's  not out to get you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell she isn't. Lillian's been  trying to nail me to a cross since  the day I met her. I'm gonna hire me  a fucking lawyer from Concord and  get this thing, this divorce thing,  rearranged. I've been thinking about  it a lot. It's like she owns Jill or  something. Nobody owns nobody,  especially not kids. And I pay her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls) Marg!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That goddamned woman. Thinks she can  cart Jill off and leave me alone  like this. I'm more than pissed,  Margie. I'm a whole lot more than  pissed. I been that plenty and I  know the difference. This is  different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marg! You got orders!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade and Margie stand. She wants to kiss him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (genuine) Tonight. Let's get together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade meets Nick halfway to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talked to Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not since last night. He took a guy  hunting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fucker shot himself. Ker-bang!  That's what it sounds like. Not on  purpose. I assume accidental.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked) Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where... how'd you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CB. Little while ago. One of the  boys on the way in picked up Jack on  the CB calling for state troopers. I  figured you'd know what really  happened. The fucking guy kill  himself? This Twombley, who the fuck  is he, anyhow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I... I've been out on the grader  all morning. Twombley's summer people.  Massachusetts. Friend of Gordon's.  It was his idea for Jack to take him  hunting. (suddenly engaged) I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margie steps over as Wade exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't care for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop being jealous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine looks up from her desk as Wade pulls the grader in the lot, jumps out, heads for his car. Laviviere stands  outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the hurry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hunting accident. Jack and Twombley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured you already heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgent) Twombley, Jesus. We got to get moving:  I got to get up there. How would I  know? C'mon, you drive. We'll take  my truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They head for LaRiviere's blue 4x4 Dodge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon and Wade drive up the same road Jack took Twombley Wade fiddles with the CB. No use: static.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck. Turn it off. (Wade does) All you heard was there was some  kinda accident?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twombley's shot. I heard that. Not  Jack. He's okay, I assume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck. You don't know how bad or  anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean Twombley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Wade, I mean Twombley. Put out  that cigarette. Fuck. Fuck. Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LaRiviere grunts disapproval as Wade slips the butt out h window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He more than likely just shot himself  in the foot or something. That's  what usually happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shoulda sent you instead of Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you had. I'd rather be deer  hunting instead of freezing my ass  on that fucking grader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't the hunter Jack is. And he  can't drive the grader worth shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahead, they see flashing lights and cars. A white emergen vehicle passes, jolting the pickup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened) That must've been Twombley. Jesus. I  bet that was Twombley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to follow them to  Littleton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get to the top and talk to  Jack first. He'll know what happened.  He fucking better. If this coulda  been avoided, I'll put that kid's  ass in a sling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade pulls behind three state trooper cars. Jack stands j with the TROOPERS, one of whom holds a German shepherd on leash. LaRiviere and Wade jump out. Jack, suddenly seriou turns to LaRiviere:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard the news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear Twombley got shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade walks over to trooper ASA BROWN, pets the shepherd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch the dog, Wade. Takes a mind  to, he'll tear your fucking head  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack) Bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-thirty at close range.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will he make it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes head) D.O.A. Blew the bastard wide open.  Had a hole in back you could put  your head into. Pretty big hole in  front too. You could've put your  fist into that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack) You see it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. Heard it. We wasn't far apart.  I spotted this buck, then I heard  the gun go off and Twombley was gone.  I looked over the little cliff we  was using for a stand and there the  fucker was, deader'n shit. Called it  right in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is gonna be one fucking mess to  clean up. Twombley's son-in-law and  daughter are up the weekend. Didn't  you say you'd seen him, Wade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seen 'em. Near ran me over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna tell 'em, Gordon? You knew  the old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck. My day's already  ruined. (to Wade) Give me the keys. You can go back  with Jack. You still got a shitload  of plowing to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't done, if that's what you  mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something bugging you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. A few things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, right now we're not too  interested. Finish up what you gotta  do, then you can get bugged on your  own time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown walks off with shepherd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack) Might as well take the rest of the  day off. You look sort of fucked up.  You've been paid for the day, anyhow,  right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly. I mean, he never paid  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll get your money. Don't talk to  any newspapers about this. Twombley's  a big deal down in Massachusetts,  you know. Tell them your lawyer says  you shouldn't comment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawyer? I don't need no lawyer, do  I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course not. Just say it, that's  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade watches LaRiviere get into his pickup, drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd Twombley get shot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offers cigarette) No, I mean whereabouts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points) A half mile in, along the old lumber  road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bring him up yourself? That's a  steep climb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ambulance guys lugged him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stayed away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you get the blood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What blood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On your sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Musta... How'd I know? What're you  doing, playing cop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta make a report to Fish and  Game. I was just wondering, that's  all. What'd he do, to shoot himself,  I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck knows? Musta slipped or  something. I just heard the gun go  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never seen a man shot before. Not  even in the service. Must be  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I didn't actually see him do  it. Like I said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saw him do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck you telling me, Wade?  I never seen the guy get shot, I  told you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You musta seen him get shot. I know  you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get the fuck outta here. You're  not making any sense, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk over to Jack's burgundy pickup. Wade eyes the r in the gun rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's your old twenty-gauge, and  that there's the new Browning you  was showing me last night. This must  be Twombley's gun. Brand new. Very  fancy tooling. Probably fired one  time. It's a beautiful piece of work. (touches it) But what the hell, Jack, I guess you  deserve it. Right's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starts engine) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twombley sure as hell won't be  shooting it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sure as hell won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late. Wade Whitehouse, lying in bed with an icepack on hi cheek, talks on the phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rolfe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, brother, look, I was calling  cause -- has there been anything on  TV in Boston about a hunting accident  with a guy named Twombley, Evan  Twombley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was something. It happened up  your way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know him -- the kid that was  with him. Maybe you do too. Jack  Hewitt. He works for LaRiviere with  me. He's my best friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, it's late. I know you're  probably at Toby's, but I'm in bed  reading. We got different habits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not tonight. I'm in bed too. I'm  calling because I need you to listen.  You're supposed to be a smart guy.  You're a professor. I got this theory.  Jack says he didn't see Twombley  shot but he did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade's theory -- in black-and-white: Twombley's footing s Jack turns to watch. Twombley's gun hits frozen rocks, fi blows a hole through his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll come out Jack lied and the  kid'll get hung for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was scheduled to testify for a  committee investigating organized  crime in New England and the  construction business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twombley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think Jack shot him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were out deer hunting, right?  Jack probably heard the gun go off,  then came back and found the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another theory: Black-and-white. Jack sees a figure run f Twombley's body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade shifts the phone from ear to ear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lillian was here. In Lawford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night before the shooting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Picked up Jill. She was supposed to  visit for the weekend for Halloween.  She wanted to go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill. I was thinking of getting a  lawyer. Maybe you can help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A divorce lawyer. A custody lawyer.  You know, 'cause of Jill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIMECUT: mobile homes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think about it. You're  exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get to feeling like a whipped dog  some days, Rolfe, and some night I'm  going to bite back. I swear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't you already done a bit of  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, I haven't. Not really. I've  growled a little, but I haven't bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound of GUNSHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade's bubble-top Fairlane drives through snow covered hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fairlane is parked outside a substantial summer house with a wide porch and frozen pond. The "speeding" BMW in drive. Wade knocks on the front door. An 8 year-old boy  answers the door. Wade speaks; the boy goes back inside. MRS. GORDON, 30, delicate, beautiful, wearing a dark gree robe, comes to the door. Her eyes are red-rimmed. Wade ha seen her before, but not this close. He feels awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was... I'm Wade Whitehouse. I was  wondering, is your husband here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's asleep. We were up very late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes, I'm... I want to say that  I'm real sorry about your father,  Mrs. Twombley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gordon. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yeah, I suppose. Sure. I just  had a little business to settle with  Mr. Gordon. I'm the local police  officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something about my father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. No, it's a... it's a traffic  thing. No big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't it wait, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEL GORDON, 40, dark-eyed, wearing a tartan robe, steps b his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whitehouse. Next time, phone ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mel folds his arms. His wife goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, 'Next time, phone ahead.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. Mr. Gordon, when I  come all the way to serve somebody a  summons, I don't call ahead for an  appointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm issuing you a ticket. Moving  violation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving violation! I just got out of  bed and you're telling me you're  giving me a goddamn speeding ticket?  Now? Are you nuts? Is that it,  Whitehouse? You're nuts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (writing) Yesterday morning, you passed a  stopped school bus, which was flashing  its lights, then you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops Wade's arm) Hold on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wrenches hand free) Don't ever put your hands on me, Mr.  Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking about a goddamned  ticket, from when I passed you at  the school where you were deciding  to hold up traffic while dreaming of  becoming a traffic cop or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give me a hard time, Mr. Gordon.  I'm just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doing your fucking job. I know. I  watch television too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Here's your ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (refusing ticket) You get the hell out of my house  now, asshole. And know this -- you  are going to be a lucky asshole if I  haven't got you fired before the day  is out. I can do it with one phone  call, and I'm pissed enough to do it  now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mel Gordon moves Wade out of the door, slams it. Wade ste away, looks back at the house. Mrs. Gordon watches him fr the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wood frame house off the main drag. Snowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade and Margie, post-coital:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's sort of sensitive, I guess.  More than most. But he'll be okay in  a few weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something funny about that  shooting. There's lots funny about  it, actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard he was drunk at Toby's last  night and got in a fight with Hettie.  He drove off without her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure, I'm positive it didn't  happen the way Jack says it did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Jack's turned into one of those  men who are permanently angry. He  used to be a sweet kid, but it's  like, when he found out he couldn't  play ball anymore, he changed. Now  he's like everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been wondering if maybe Jack  shot Twombley, instead of Twombley  shooting himself. I've been wondering  maybe Jack shot him on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade! How can you even think such a  thing? Why would Jack Hewitt do that,  shoot Twombley on purpose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black-and-white. A further theory: Jack bends over the fa Twombley, holds a tarp to protect his chest from blood sp He shoots Twombley with his own gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack doesn't need money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody needs money. Except guys  like Twombley and that sonofabitch  son-in-law of his. People like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack wouldn't kill for it. Besides,  who would pay him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of people. Guy like Evan  Twombley, Boston union official,  probably got lots of people want to  see him dead. The Government's been  investigating his links with the  Mafia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) The Mafia hire Jack Hewitt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I just know Jack's lying about  what happened. He just seemed -- I  know that kid, what he's like inside.  He's a lot like I was at his age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't have done anything like  that, shot someone for money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not for money. But, if somebody'd  given me half a damned excuse -- I  was pretty fucked up, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) But not now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade sits on the edge of the bed, sighs. Lapses into thou Margie caresses his back, kisses it. He winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you gonna get that tooth fixed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade looks at her, brushes the hair off her face:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see what you looked like as a  kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You knew me as a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but never what you looked like.  Not really. Never really studied  your face, like now. I was never  able to see you as a kid when you  were a kid until now, this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After making love. I like it. It's  nice to see that in a grown-up person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade walks naked to the kitchen, returns with two beers, for Marg. He gets in bed. She, thinking, sips:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think, do you still think  it's a good idea to press this custody  thing -- just now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm her father -- supposed to be,  but I'm not able to. Yes. Yes, I am.  It may be the only thing in my life  I've been so clear about wanting.  Even if it takes a big fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then... I guess you have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (silence) There's another thing I've been  thinking about. I don't know how you  feel about the idea, Margie, because  we've never talked about it. But  I've been thinking lately, I've been  thinking we should get married  sometime. You and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncertain) Oh, Wade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about it, that's  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been married twice --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was to the same woman. I was just  a kid... (Marg looks) It's not like a marriage proposal or  anything, just a thought. Something  for you and me to talk about and  think about. You know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. I'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her. His jaw winces in pain.

dialogues.speaker: THE FLASHBACK CONTINUES
dialogues.text: Glen Whitehouse, plastered, yells at Wade, age 13:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got sons, Goddamnit, oh my God,  have I got sons! Wade? Rolfe?  Elbourne? You love me boys? Do you  love your Pop? Of course you do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, frightened, retreats as Sally enters in her houseco

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen, stop --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, Sally, you are such a  Goddamned good person! Capital G.  You are so much better than I am, I  who am no good at all, you who are a  truly good person, like a fucking  saint! Beyond fucking com-pare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen reaches for the Canadian Club; Sally tries to block hand. Glen pulls his arm from hers, clipping her cheek wi the bottle. Sally gasps, grabs her cheek. Wade pushes between them, protecting his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My big boy bursting out of the seams  of his jeans!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop clenches his fist. Wade vainly looks Rolfe's directio for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You little prick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop's fist comes crashing down. Wade raises his arms to  protect himself. Wade's arm bone CRACKS with the blow. Wa grimaces in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen, stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margie gets into Wade's idling Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, washed and changed, drives; Marg sits beside him. T head north. Deer rifles echo from the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you tell them? (no answer) That we were coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think it's proper for a  fella to introduce his girl to his  parents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know your parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to pick up my divorce  papers. For the lawyer. It won't  take long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun slants over Parker Mountain; they pull up. The house, once white, is peeling. Polyurethane flaps over dark wind The 1960 red Ford pickup sits long frozen in the open bar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting out) Are you sure they're home? Did you  call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck's here. Looks like they've  stayed inside since the snow started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stamp their feet on the porch; Wade turns the knob.  Locked. It seems abandoned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think they're alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course! I would've heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know for Christ's sake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They round the house, try the back door. Wade knocks loud GLEN WHITEHOUSE, 70, opens the door, stands inside. He we long underwear, stained woolen trousers, slippers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop, Pop, you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen shuffles toward the stove; they follow. He starts a  fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Pop, how can you stand the  cold, dressed like that? Where's Ma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember Margie Fogg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Wickham's. Been a while. Like  some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you and Ma doing? Haven't seen  you in town for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're alright. Your Ma's sleeping.  You want me to get her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop goes to the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Marg) Jesus. Nothing's changed around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Ma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been heating the house? Not  just with the stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a furnace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not using it today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's broke I guess. There's an  electric in the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe Wade should take a look at it.  Your pipes'll freeze. (Pop nods) Wade, would you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, concerned, pushes open the BEDROOM door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma? It's Wade. Can I come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps inside. On the bed, Sally Whitehouse, wrapped in blankets, lies dead. He walks over, beside the small elec heater, touches her forehead. Her skin is chalk white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margie steps into the doorway. Pop joins:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee's perked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did she die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is...? She's dead then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I checked on her. She had the electric  heater. Cold don't bother her as  much as me. Which is why I give her  the heater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kneels over mother) Is there something wrong with the  phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you call and have the  furnace fixed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade. I thought she was alright.  Till this morning she was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop goes to the dresser, pours himself Canadian Club. Wad opens his mother's mouth, attempts respiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes me sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sits) Makes me sad it was her. Instead of  me. I shoulda froze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROLFE WHITEHOUSE, 38, drives his four-door Toyota west:  through Massachusetts, toward New Hampshire. His face bes tolerance, objectivity -- in short, education. It's also  Wade's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade called me, as usual, late at  night. I knew it was Wade -- no one  else calls me at that hour -- and I  was ready to listen to another chapter  in one of his ongoing sagas. There  was the detective story concerning  the shooting of Evan Twombley and  the family melodrama about Wade's  custody fight with Lillian. But not  this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rolfe's Toyota sits with other cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade was telling a different story,  or so it seemed then, one in which I  myself was a character. He had called  to tell me that sometime the previous  night our mother had died, and he  had discovered the body when he'd  gone over to visit her and our father  with Margie Fogg. Pop was okay, but  kind of out of it. Worse than usual,  maybe, though no drunker than usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friends and relatives gather in the living room: Wade, Ro Glen, LaRiviere, Margie, an aging couple, REVEREND DOUGHT 30, thin, wearing glasses and an avocado-green suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finishing a beer) Shouldn't we get this show on the  road, now that Rolfe's here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one moves. LaRiviere checks his watch. Wade shrugs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pointless to stand around in church  with nothing to do, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Jill? Is Lillian bringing  her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margie's face tells Rolfe he's touched on a sensitive sub

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll be at the church and the  cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade opens the frig, takes out another beer:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone else want one? Rolfe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. I don't drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you holding up, Wade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine, fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You Rolfe? (Rolfe nods) I remember you from high school.  You're a teacher now? Harvard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B.U.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't seen you around. I don't  suppose there's much reason for you  to come this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rev. Doughty calls for Glen Whitehouse, who has been sitt silent, drinking, to join the others:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Glen, join us. Let's kneel for  a moment of prayer before the service.  Wade? Rolfe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, expressionless, looks at Rolfe. Rolfe, embarrassed, trying to do the right thing, helps his father kneel besi Rev. Doughty. The others join the circle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reproving) Wade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Heavenly Father, Lord of Hosts,  we come to Thee to beseech Thy  blessings and commend to You the  soul of our beloved wife and mother,  Sally Whitehouse, to be one with You  and walk with You --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop mutters something. Wade, Rolfe and Marg exchange glan He mutters louder:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...goddamned hair on her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises over LaRiviere, turns, exclaims:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a one of you is worth a goddamned  hair on that good woman's head!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doughty freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop! Don't do this now, Pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop knocks back a drink as the others stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll head on over to the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a difficult time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon and the couple file out. Doughty, Glen, Rolfe, Wad and Margie remain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, it's no big deal, Pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising fists) Come on, smart guy. Tell how it's no  big deal. Tell me how a single one  of you is worth a single hair on  that woman's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give up this demon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go fuck yourself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, eyes blazing, squares off. Son to father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, just leave it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mocking) Listen to your little brother. 'Wade,  just leave it.' Candy-asses. All of  you. That's what I've got for  children. Candyasses. 'Wade, just  leave it.' Praise the Lord! 'Just  leave it!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade stiffens. Pop cocks his fist. Marg, screaming, jumps between them as Pop swings. The old man bounces blows off Margie's arms and shoulders Wade pushes Marg aside, grabs his father in a bear hug an walks him backwards, flat against the wall. Wade releases him. Pop, frail, collapses to the floor. Wade kneels over him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you ever touch her again, I'll  kill you. I swear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Townspeople and friends cluster around the gravesite: Pop LaRiviere, Jack and Hettie, LaCoy, Chub Merritt, Nick, Ji Lillian, Jill and Horner, Rolfe, Wade and Margie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day of the funeral was almost  springlike. The snowline crossed New  Hampshire west to east, retreating  northward to Concord where it melted  by midmorning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rev. Doughty finishes. The mourners exchange farewells. W looks at Lillian. Margie and Rolfe, escorting Wade's fath let him be. He walks over, hugs Jill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lillian) I'm glad you're here. Can you stay  for a while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lillian hesitates, shakes her head 'no.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever come to your father's grave  anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not anymore. It's too... it's  too far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've done all our talking, Wade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let the past be. (beat) I'm sorry about your mother. I liked  her. You never know how much women  like that suffer. It's like they  live their lives with the sound turned  off -- and then they're gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tugging at Lillian) Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has an ice-skating lesson at  four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm taking ice-skating, Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses Jill, says goodbyes, walks back to Rolfe and Ma Ahead, LaRiviere walks with Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade and Rolfe leave Margie and Pop in the kitchen as the step out back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's dig out Pop's truck before the  skin of the snow freezes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They grab snow shovels propped against the porch, walk to the barn. Firewood's stacked alongside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shafts of light filter through the ramshackle structure. snow drift nearly buries Glen's red truck. Wade and Rolfe break away the packed snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Margie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, do you still plan to get  married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. She'll probably quit her job  and stay out here with Pop. We can't  leave him alone here, he'll set the  damn place on fire. With Jill here a  lot, it'll be good to have Margie  around. Things are going to change  in that department, by the way. I  got a custody lawyer in Concord. I'm  gonna see him tomorrow. All hell's  gonna break loose, but it's worth  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They finish clearing the snow. Wade gets in the truck, st the engine. Rolfe waits for Wade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to let the gas run out. I  don't want the bastard driving drunk,  and he's always drunk now. After,  we'll hide the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything new about the shooting?  Twombley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctant) I guess it was an accident, like  everybody thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to know what I think happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade opens the glove compartment, finds a bottle of Canad Club. He unscrews the cap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find them everywhere. (swigs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think your first response to the  Twombley shooting was the correct  one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That it wasn't an accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then who shot him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, your friend, I think. Jack  Hewitt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motive. You gotta have a motive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd pay him that kind of money?  Not the mob. They got their own guys.  Specialists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agreeing) They wouldn't deal with a guy like  Jack. Who else benefits if Twombley  is suddenly dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swigs) I don't know. You tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. It's likely there are people  in the union who don't want Twombley  to testify. They probably include  his son-in-law who's vice-president  and will probably be the next  president. I read that in the papers.  What's his name, Mel Gordon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, the guy with the BMW I told  you about. I did, didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's my theory. Twombley, unaware  of illegal union loans or whatever,  starts nosing around cause of the  investigation and finds out. Finds  out his son-in-law is involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Mel Gordon wouldn't want a  professional hit. That'd make the  feds dig deeper. He wants an accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hunting accident is perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, around here, you shoot somebody  in the woods, you say it was an  accident, you get fined fifty bucks  and your hunting license lifted.  Jack's probably saying the guy shot  himself cause he ain't got his deer  yet and don't want his license pulled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck sputters, stops. Wade pulls the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too neat. Things ain't that  neat. It makes me mad. That somebody  can pay to kill somebody, his own  father-in-law, and not be punished  for it. Don't that piss you off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not particularly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right's right, goddamnit! Don't you  care what's right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I care about what happened. The truth.  I'm a student of history, remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is down. Wade tucks the keys in a knotted board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
