dialogues.text: I was thinking about that story you  told me, about Pop and chopping the  firewood out of the ice and after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate to disappoint you, but I don't  think it happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it happened. Why would I  lie about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It may have happened, but not the  way you said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I wouldn't remember a thing  like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't me. I wasn't there, but I  heard about it. When I heard about  it, it was about Elbourne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd have to go digging in Vietnam  to ask him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Elbourne and Mom took you to the  doctor and told him you fell from  the hay loft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Well, I never heard that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember clearly cause when I heard  I became real careful around Pop. I  was a careful child and I became a  careful adult, but at least I wasn't  afflicted by that man's violence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs again) That's what you think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rolfe looks out: the cobalt sky has turned black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta head back. It's a long drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade walks in as Jack and Jimmy prepare to head out, thei drilling rig loaded with pipe. Gordon yells at Jack:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put out that fucking cigarette!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack opens the truck ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not there, asshole. Flush it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hewitt trudges to the john.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LaRiviere smiles, goes to his office as Wade hangs his co in his locker. Jack cruises over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fucking out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of this fucking job. This job  sucks. Working outside in the winter  sucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack gets in the cab of the drilling truck. Wade follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open the door, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you quit now, you want out  so bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open the door. We're late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it -- you got enough money  now. Head out for California. Surf's  up, Jack, and you're digging wells  in the snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean I got money? I'm as  broke as you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade grins, goes to activate the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looney Tunes, Jack. Fucking Looney  Tunes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drilling truck pulls out the garage, onto the road. F the opposite direction a black BMW slows, enters. Mel Gor Wade, all eyes and ears, watches. Mel Gordon parks in fro of the office, gets out. Elaine calls:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gordon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boss in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes indeedy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade flips the door switch. Mel Gordon and LaRiviere talk Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The South Main Street office of J. Battle Hand, lawyer.  Concord is a real town, with traffic, stores, people with places to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J. BATTLE HAND, 60, sits in a wheel chair behind his desk Wade, uncomfortable in work clothes, tries not to show it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I screwed up the divorce. I agreed  with everything she said. I wanted  her to like me. I just want to be a  good father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would help if you were married,  if there was someone at home while  you work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I plan to. Soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How soon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This spring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. It would help if there were  some drug or alcohol abuse on the  part of your ex-wife. Sexual problems  upsetting to the child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks pretty hopeless, don't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not exactly. I'll look at the  divorce decree, see if we can get it  redrawn. Interview your daughter.  Jill, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. I'll need a $500 retainer. You  can mail it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. How much... how much will the  whole thing cost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to say. If we go for custody,  depositions, psychiatric evaluations,  it could drag on. Ten or twelve  thousand dollars. She could win on  appeal. If we just want to get the  visitation rights redrawn, assuming  they're unduly restrictive, it  wouldn't be more than twenty-five  hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sensing situation) You might be better off legally as  well as financially to just go for  the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know. The custody suit thing  was just my getting back at her. I'm  not as dumb as I look. Whatever you  say. I love my daughter. (Hand nods) I'll send you the five hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade stands; Hand motors to the door. Wade puts his finge in his mouth. His tooth throbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fairlane squad car in its customary spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade and Gordon speak. LaRiviere is relaxed, open: a "new Gordon."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about the long lunch. My clutch  is going out again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever think of getting a new car,  Wade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On what you pay me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine! Call Chub Meritt and have  him pick up Wade's car, fix the  clutch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Wade) Use the pickup. I'll bill it to the  town. You're the town police officer  and the town police officer should  have a decent car. You want a new  car or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I have to do for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, Wade, I've been thinking.  You don't get enough appreciation  around here and it's time we changed  things a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw Mel Gordon in here this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He say anything about the summons I  tried to give him? Sonofabitch  wouldn't accept it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, that wasn't smart. Going out  right after the man's father-in-law  shot himself. Let it go. Call it a  favor to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mel's doing some business with me.  It's nice to do favors for people  you do business with. He was in a  hurry. No big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was before Twombley was shot.  Before he knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the difference? Take my truck,  take a rest -- stop worrying about  Mel Gordon. Have you decided what to  do with your old man's place -- he  going to stay there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes out cigarette) Want to buy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't light that in here. I'm  allergic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't. You interested?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and Mel Gordon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice rising) Always count on old Wade for a good  screwing. Why should I always pay  more, sell cheap? Why should you  guys make all the money. You and Mel  and Jack. Right's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade pulls out Bic, lights cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waving arms) Out! Out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade smiles, exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, driving Gordon's 4x4 with running lights and roll b takes 29 toward Pop's farm. A pickup passes him: Jack Hewitt's burgundy Ford. Wade st Jack turns up Parker Mountain -- the road to the accident scene. Something's up. Wade turns and follows. Jack's fresh tracks lead the way. Hewitt is driving fast. Wade keeps up. Jack, far ahead, approaches the accident scene. Stops. Ni has fallen. Wade comes over a low rise, spots Jack's pickup. He kills the lights, parks to block Jack's exit. Silence. Footsteps in the snow. Wade watches, listens. Wh he doing? Looking for evidence? The burgundy pickup engine suddenly ROARS -- Jack's back at the wheel -- the tires squeal, spit snow as he spins p Wade. Wade starts his engine, gives pursuit. The pickups gun th engines, bumper to bumper, down mountain roads, lumber ro rocky trails. Wild headlamps their only guide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trail turns sharply past a shallow beaver pond -- too  sharply for Jack. He crashes through a stand of skinny bi straight out onto the pond. The pickup's momentum carries across the pond. Wade drops into first gear, follows, his headlights refle ice. He drives directly to Jack, bumper to bumper, headli to headlight. Jack sticks his head out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You crazy sonofabitch! You'll sink  us both! Get off the fucking ice!  Get off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade doesn't budge. Jack backs away; Wade inches forward. Hewitt's trapped. Trees behind him. Neither truck has tra on ice. Jack steps out, swinging his fists wildly. Wade gets out. Jacks grabs his rifle, points it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll shoot you, Wade, I swear it!  I'll fucking shoot you dead if you  don't move away from that truck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade backs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't move! I'll shoot you dead if  you move!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack gets back in his pickup, maneuvers it slowly around Dodge, crosses the ice and is gone. Wade stands in darkness. The only sound his idling truck, the wind. Then a third sound -- the snap of ice. Ice crac ripple from the middle of the pond. Ice planes tip around the truck. LaRiviere's snazzy Dodge slips, descends, disappears. Headlights glow under water, then go out. "Our Business I Going In The Hole." Wade, alone in darkness, plops into the water, paddles to shore. Freezing, he finds Jack's tire tracks in the snow. bangs his jaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car drops Wade off. "Home Made Cooking."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade enters the empty diner. His clothes frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father's in back, Wade. Marg  had to babysit him. She moved in  with you, huh? (looking closer) What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade goes to the kitchen. Glen Whitehouse, washing dishes with Margie, looks up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, the prodigal son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About fucking time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, got me a new job, second cook  and bottle washer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Pop, let's go home. I  got waylaid. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fuck you got waylaid. You follow  your prick around like it was your  nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enters) Can it, Whitehouse. (to Wade) Get him out of here. It was funny at  first, but I'm tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's clothes in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade's old man talks as he dresses:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go home? What home is that?  Your home? My home? Let's have a  talk about that. You're fucking sly,  Wade. Your mother's dead so she can't  make any excuses for you anymore!  You gotta deal with me! No more sugar  tit, asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, redressed, enters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop, for Christ's sake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you can take me now? Come  on, try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margie and Nick guide pere et fils to MARG'S CAR. Nick sp to her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marg, get out of this. Fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marg drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade leans close to his father, his breath on his:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you would die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop spits directly into Wade's face, raises his arm. Wade catches it, twists it. Margie shrieks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it! Stop it! Just stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do, glaring as they approach the farmhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade looks in the bedroom, sees Margie sleeping, goes to bathroom. He peers, stands before the sink, washes his hands slowly Drying his hands, he looks into the mirror, startled by t image of his own face. A phone conversation plays over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit, Rolfe, I glanced up and  there he was, only it was me. But it  was like I had never seen myself  before. It was a stranger's face.  Hard to explain. You fly on automatic  pilot, like I was doing all night,  and you disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade sits alone in the darkened room, speaking on the pho His cigarette glows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you accidentally see your body,  or your face, or whatever, and you  don't know who the hell it belongs  to. Strange. It's the business with  the old man, I know, and how  incredibly pissed I was at him, and  also chasing Jack Hewitt like that,  and the Goddamned truck going through  the ice, not to mention Margie's  being so upset -- one thing on top  of another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you gotta hear this. You won't  believe it. Mel Gordon had come by  to visit LaRiviere and so now I'm in  his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade's theory expanded: Jack and Gordon argue in the offi An extension of Scene 55. Like Wade's other theories, in  black-and-white:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's on to us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit! What are we gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I can buy him off. I gotta  talk to Mel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't buy Wade off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We bought you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade drives Margie's car toward LaRiviere's. In his rear  view window he spots Chick Ward driving Chub Merritt's to truck, lights blinking, pulling LaRiviere's pickup like a dead fish. He pulls over, lets it pass. He's parked in front of Alma Pittman's house. A sign on the lawn reads, "Alma Pittman, Town Clerk." He looks at the house, decides to go in. Wade walks up th shoveled steps, knocks on the door. ALMA, 60, wearing pla shirt and slacks, greets him with a smile:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade! Come in! Have a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They step into Alma's living room/office. She's been keep the town secrets for as long as anyone can remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got yourself a computer, Alma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been putting my files into it. You  take sugar and milk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit by her desk at the bay window. She studies him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright, Wade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. Why? I got this damned  tooth, I got a few things bugging  me, like everybody else. But I'm  okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you look... sad. Upset. I don't  mean to pry. I'm sorry about your  mother. It was a nice funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma, I think there's some dirty  business going on in this town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always has been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is maybe worse than you and I  are used to. (beat) What I'm talking about, I'm talking  about murder. Among other things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evan Twombley, the union boss who  got shot. Somebody murdered him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Jack Hewitt, the kid I work  with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon LaRiviere examines his damaged pickup outside the  Shell station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade finishes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...if Jack told the truth, he could  be free by the time he's my age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes things are simpler than  you think. Let me ask you a question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't believe me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crosses to her desk) About Jack? No. Have you checked out  the tax bill on your father's farm  lately?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know he's due for the last two  years. I was thinking of paying it  when the insurance comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has anybody offered to buy it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a mater of fact, yes. LaRiviere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma punches her computer. Dozens of items flash up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all the real estate  transactions in this town the last  year. Most of it unused land. Most  of it for little more than the back  taxes owed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She punches again: only three items.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is from three years ago. Some  difference, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking) What is the Northcountry Development  Association?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went down to Concord to check it  out. The president is Mel Gordon.  The vice-president and treasurer is  Gordon LaRiviere. Those boys are  buying up the mountain, Wade. $364,000  this year. I believe that's out of  LaRiviere's league.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twombley involved?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He musta found out. They had to get  rid of him. And Jack'll get blamed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the figures show is that Gordon  LaRiviere is going to be a very rich  man using his position as Selectman.  In a year or two, you won't recognize  this town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade storms in, shouting. Jack and Jimmy choose donuts by the file cabinet. LaRiviere's behind his desk. Wade's too makes it hard for him to talk without pain:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sneaky sonofabitch! I've got  your number now, Gordon! All these  years I actually thought you were a  decent man. (pounds fists on desk) Can you believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, combative, looks at Wade. Gordon stands before Jack can speak:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, you're done. (extends hand) Let me have the shop keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack and Jimmy) You two, don't you get it? He's using  you. You're his slaves. (soft) Jesus Christ, Jack, don't you see  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The key, Wade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you can have the key. It's the  key that's kept me locked to you all  these years. I give it to you with  pleasure. (passes key) Now I'm free. See how easy it is,  Jack? All you got to do is give back  what the man gave you, and you're  free of him. (turns to leave) I've got to call my brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade's phone conversation plays OVER as he goes to Margie car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what it means. I'm just running  out of ways to use it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone conversation continues as Wade drives to Merritt's  Shell station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To help, Jack, of course -- and to  nail those sonsofbitches, the Two  Gordons. That's what Alma calls them.  Jesus, Rolfe, whose side are you on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care of the little things first,  the things that are distracting you  from taking care of the big things.  Call Chub Merritt, get your car back,  call a dentist, for God's sake, and  get your tooth pulled, don't trust  the locals, get your facts straight  and go straight to the state police.  Let them work on this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHICK WARD, 30, Chub Merritt's mechanic, greets Wade outs the station. We join their conversation:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The good news is we haven't got to  your car yet. The bad news --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell me when you'll have it  fixed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- the bad news is there's a problem  with Gordon's truck what somebody  drove through the ice last night.  Figured you'd know something about  that, Wade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Yeah. I know about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LaRiviere says he ain't gonna pay  for the fixin' of your car. A couple  hundred for the clutch. I got some  more bad news. Wanna hear it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chub says you're fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't fire me. LaRiviere already  did that this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a Selectman. The town. He said  to tell you to turn your badge in  and clean out your office. I'm  supposed to pull the CB and police  light out of your car. They're town  property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, open phone book in hand, walks back and forth speak into the receiver. Margie looks up from the KITCHEN table an old newspaper in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, you can't take me  today? I told you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other party has hung up. Margie stands, upset. Wade s the phone down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What on earth is happening to you?  Why are you acting this way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my tooth! My fucking tooth! I  can't even think anymore because of  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you talking. You got fired  this morning, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, that's temporary, believe me.  There's so much shit gonna hit the  fan the next few days, my getting  fired by LaRiviere and Merritt won't  matter a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop enters from outside with firewood, passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get another job. People are  going to need me. After this is over,  they'll make me into a Goddamned  hero. You wait: you'll see, I'll  deliver. I'll be the best father who  ever lived. You need me, even Pop,  for Christ's sake, he needs me. This  town needs me. Maybe now they think  they can send me howling into a corner  like a kicked dog, but my God, it'll  be different soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margie's face falls. She retreats from the room as he spe taking her coat and pocketbook. Wade and his old man, she thinks: just the same. Wade looks out the window and she gets in her car, drives off. Wade holds his inflamed jaw; he can hardly see straight. turns on the TV in the living room, boosts the volume. Pop comes back in the room, gets the Canadian Club, pours himself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave the bottle out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop growls, goes back to wrestling on the TV. Wade walks the cabinet, removes a pair of pliers from the tool drawe goes toward the bathroom. In the BATHROOM, Wade opens his mouth -- it hurts -- take bite of whisky, sets the bottle on the toilet tank. He looks at the stranger in the mirror, reaches inside hi mouth with the pliers. Prying his mouth open, Wade Whiteh locks the pliers onto a large molar in the back, squeezes and pulls. He steadies himself, pulls again, yanking the pliers from his mouth. The bloody rotted tooth clatters in the sink. takes another bite of whisky. Rolfe's voice plays over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will say I should have known  terrible things were about to happen,  and perhaps I should have. But even  so, what could I have done by then?  Wade never went inside. He lived  almost wholly out there on his skin,  with no interior space to retreat  to, even in a crisis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade takes another swig, sets the whisky bottle in the LI ROOM beside the TV set. Wade and Pop exchange looks. Wade exits through the KITCHEN, snatching his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade spits blood into the snow as he grabs a gallon can o gasoline from under the porch. He crosses to the barn, prepares to pour the gas into the beat-up red truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade's Ford pickup passes J. Battle Hand's office, keeps  going. Grass peeks through the snow at this lower altitud

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade parks the truck, walks past leafless bushes to a cha gray split-level with pink shutters. He pushes the door b the first notes of "Frere Jacques" play. Lillian opens the door; Jill's footsteps approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait there. She'll be right out. (looks back) Is there snow on the ground up in  Lawford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, lots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jill) See. Get your boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going back inside) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have her back tomorrow night by six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem. Look, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make me sick. I can't believe  you've sunk so low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Low as what? What have I done? It's  bad to want to see your own daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I'm talking about. For  what you're doing to me and to the  child you say you love so much. Love.  You won't get away with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill returns, wearing parka and boots, heads out with her father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, honey! Call me tonight if you  want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade and Jill approach the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we going in this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. My car's in the shop. This'll  be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pretty old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It belongs to Pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandpa. My father. It's his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade opens the truck door. Jill climbs in with her overni bag, looks back to the door where Lillian watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ford heads north.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winking) How about a Big Mac?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy won't let me eat fast food.  You know that. It's bad for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, we can always sneak a Big  Mac. And a cherry turnover. Your  favorite. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't have nothing, Jill. We  need lunch. Mr. Pizza?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same thing, Daddy. Mommy says --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what Mommy says. I'm in charge  today, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. So we'll get what you want.  What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop for a light. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, I guess. I guess I can wait  till we get home. Maybe we'll stop  by Wickham's for a hamburger when we  get to Lawford. That suit you? You  always like Wickham's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking ahead) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Wade looks over at Jill and realizes she is crying

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, Jill, I'm sorry. What's  the matter, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shoves her clenched fists hard against her legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't cry. Please, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (regains composure) What are you sorry for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. For the food business.  I guess. I just thought, you know,  we'd sneak a Big Mac on Mommy, like  we used to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quick) You can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill looks away. Wade pulls a six-pack from under the sea pulls off a beer, takes a swig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet) That's illegal, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a policeman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. Not anymore. I'm nothing  anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade and Jill enter Wickham's, crowded with out-of-state  hunters at the end of the deer season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jillie, you want a cheese grilled  sandwich?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called a grilled cheese sandwich,  you dub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, flaring, reaches across the counter and grabs Nick the shirtfront! Nick's arm knocks over a cup of coffee. The diner goes silent. Hunters look up. Jill's face is wh she starts to cry. Wade looks over -- it takes him a moment to react -- bend down, comforting her. He wipes her nose with a napkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill, please, it's alright. Nothing  happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rigid) Okay, let's go home, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They head for the door. Nick eases over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delicate) Wade, I got a message for you. (Wade turns) Jack Hewitt, he's looking for you.  Wants you to clear your stuff out of  his office in Town Hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His office. You mean my old office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess -- that's what he said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got his deer yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's out now. Somewhere on the  mountain. I'd stay away from him if  I were you. He's real pissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade takes Jill's hand, exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill waits in the old red truck parked outside. Wade emerges with cardboard boxes of office miscellany, r laid across top. He shoves the boxes and guns into the ba of the pickup, gets in and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade and Jill pull up the drive, past Margie's car, into barn. Her trunk and two side doors are open. Margie comes out back with a battered suitcase, goes to h car. She's leaving. A plastic bag of clothes sits in the  trunk. Wade and Jill get out, approach:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going somewhere, Margie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just cleaning out some of this  stuff that's built up. For the rummage  sale. And some things for the  cleaners. And the laundromat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't lie to me. You're leaving me,  I can see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly. Hi, Jill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill, suitcase in hand, looking pathetic, tries to smile. sadness passes over Wade's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurt) Marg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margie, watching him, quivers, starts to cry. She drops h suitcase, out of nowhere bawling like a baby. Wade goes over, puts his arms around her, pats her back. face is racked. He, too, seems about to cry -- if he coul In his arms Margie feels trapped, overwhelmed by Wade's  circumstances and terrible sadness. She pushes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying) Leave me alone! Leave me alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She struggles in Wade's grasp. Jill, frightened, wildly h him from behind:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave her alone! Leave her alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade moves back like a bear, covering his face and arms.  Jill, near hysterical, keeps after him, arms and fists fl Wade stumbles backwards into the snow. Jill still swings. Margie dashes to intervene as Wade swings his arms wide. Jill flies into Marg. Her nose is bleeding. Wade's caught her across the mouth and nose. She takes cover behind Mar crying. Margie and Jill stand side by side, saying nothing. Wade  looks up stunned, as if hit by a rock. Marg slowly backs  away, her arms behind her holding Jill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jill) Get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marg eases Jill into the front seat, closes the door, edg around the car slamming the trunk and gets into the drive seat. Wade stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to go home. Will you take me  home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes the front door, starts the car. She backs out drive. In her rear view mirror she sees the image of Wade recedi standing frozen, staring down at the snow. Pop emerges fr the house, looks at his son, grinning. Wade looks at his old man, that dumb devilish grin plaste on his father's face. Glen Whitehouse holds an empty whis bottle like a pistol. Hunters' gunshots echo in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Satanic delight) You! By Christ, you -- I know you. (points bottle) Yeah, you goddamn sonofabitch, I  know you. You're a goddamn fucking  piece of my heart!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dead) You don't know me. You don't know  me! (beat) So fuck you. Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah-nah-naw! You done done finally  done it! Like a man done it. Done it  right. I love you, you mean  sonofabitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop holds up the bottle, pretends to fire it at Wade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love! What the fuck do you know about  love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love! I'm made of love!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call it what you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything you know is from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bang!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade waves his old man off, trudges toward the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the Christ you going? You  sonofabitch, you leave my fucking  truck where it is! I need... Give me  the Goddamn keys! I need to get me  to town!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing in the fucking house to drink.  Not a fucking thing. My house, my  money, my truck -- stolen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know you. My goddamn father  and I don't know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade walks from the glistening snow into the dark barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade unloads the cardboard boxes filled with his office  belongings from the back of the truck and sets them on th ground. He gathers up his rifles. Suddenly! A whiskey bottle SLAMS against the back of his  head. He drops to his knees, the guns scatter. He looks u with child's fear and guilt at his father. Glen Whitehouse hovers over him, huge and ferocious: a  colossus, lifting the bottle like a jawbone. Wade cringes, scrambles for the dropped rifle. He grabs i by the barrel and, twisting around, swings it in a slow m arc, smashing the edge of the wood stock against his fath head. A cold hard CRACK of bone. Glen Whitehouse -- shriveled again, no longer mythic -- f back like a stuffed dummy. He collapses beside the empty  C.C. bottle. Wade, bleeding from the head, stands, staggers off Pop's  inert body, aims his rifle at the old man's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you now. I love you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade bolts the rifle, flicks off the safety, fires -- a l CLICK. The gun's empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Joke. You scared me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kneels down, lovingly touches the old man's face, care his lips, cheeks, nose, brows, smoothes back his stiff gr hair. Pop's eyes are clouded. Blood suddenly drips from his ear the ground. Wade rests the rifle against the truck. He bends over, sl his hands under his father's body, lifts him up. He carri Pop over to the workbench, lays him out. Groping beneath the bench, Wade finds the kerosene lamp. unscrews it, pours kerosene the length of Pop's body. Wade takes out his cigarette lighter, ignites it, holds i for a moment, places it to Glen Whitehouse. Fire spreads the length of Pop's body, bursting like a sh of yellow flame. The oil-stained bench crackles; flames s up the old weathered wall. Burning flesh and heat drive Wade backwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade stands in snow and sunlight. The entire barn is engu in flames. Black smoke billows through the clear winter s Inside Glen Whitehouse, a pyre, burns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The historical facts are known by  everyone -- all of Lawford, all of  New Hampshire, some of Massachusetts.  Facts do not make history. Our  stories, Wade's and mine, describe  the lives of boys and men for  thousands of years, boys who were  beaten by their fathers, whose  capacity for love and trust was  crippled almost at birth and whose  best hope, if any, for connection  with other human beings lay in an  elegiac detachment, as if life were  over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop's red truck is parked behind Jack Hewitt's 4x4 on a s banked road. Wade, hunting rifle pointed up, traces Jack' footsteps down the slope of the mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's how we keep from destroying in  turn our own children and terrorizing  the women who have the misfortune to  love us; how we absent ourselves  from the tradition of male violence;  how we decline the seduction of  revenge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade spots Jack poised in a spruce grove, watching for de Wade bolts his rifle, releases the safety, aims and FIRES Jack, hit in the chest, falls bleeding between trees. Blo stains the snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's truck turned up three days  later in a shopping mall in Toronto.  Even without the footprints, the  bullet, Wade's utter disappearance  seemed evidence enough of his guilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera glides from room to room, glimpsing details, fragm of former times, as if this were an historical site or  memorial. The walls resonate: lives were molded here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LaRiviere and Mel Gordon were indeed  in business. The Parker Mountain Ski  Resort is now advertised all across  the country. Jimmy Dame tends bar at  the lodge. Chub Merritt opened a  snowmobile dealership, Nick Wickham  runs the new Burger King. Margie  Fogg moved to Littleton, nearer her  mother; Lillian and Jill went with  Bob Horner to a new job in Seattle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out a window, workers gather charred timbers from the bar throw them on a truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want to believe Wade died, died  that same November, froze to death  on a bench or a sidewalk. You cannot  understand how a man, a normal man,  a man like you and me, could do such  a terrible thing. Unless the police  happen to arrest a vagrant who turns  out to be Wade Whitehouse -- or maybe  he won't be a vagrant; maybe he will  have turned himself into one of those  faceless fellows working at the video  store and lives in a town-house  apartment at the edge of town until  his mailman recognizes him from the  picture at the post office -- unless  that happens, there will be no more  mention of him and his friend Jack  Hewitt and our father. The story  will be over. Except that I continue.
